node.text:
Astra + Pfizer = ?
Moderna + Sinovac = ?

In some countries, people have received a mixture of Covid vaccines. Nicole Sy breaks down what that could mean for the world's vaccinated, and those still waiting on their first shot. (via @quicktake)

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text: Almost 30 years ago, an American court ruled that victims of the Ferdinand Marcos regime in the Philippines should be compensated — setting off one of the most ambitious and valuable treasure hunts of all time. (via @businessweek)

node.title: Where Did Marcos Hide His $10 Billion Fortune?

node.text: An anonymous donor turned a tiny Pacific coast town without a bank into the world's biggest Bitcoin experiment. Here's how life has changed on El Savaldor's Bitcoin beach. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Bitcoin Beach: The Surf Town That Went Crypto

node.text: Airbnb's $100 billion business model is built on strangers trusting each other. When things go horribly wrong, the company's secretive safety team steps in to soothe guests and hosts, help families and prevent PR disasters. (via @businessweek)

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text: The sudden cancellation of Ant Group’s IPO shocked investors, but Beijing's slapdown of Jack Ma was years in the making. And Alibaba and Ant aren't the only tech firms under scrutiny by Chinese regulators.

node.title: How China Lost Patience With Its Loudest Billionaire

node.text:
Plant-based meat used to mean burgers and sausages. Not anymore.

Using techniques from 3D printing to specially cultivated mushrooms, these companies are at the forefront of the next generation of alternative meats: whole cuts. (via @quicktake)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 20, 2021. May be an image of wrist watch and text that says 'Here'saforgotten relic from 1995: the Apple watch QUARTZ JAPAN MOV'T Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Apple Watch – these two words no doubt bring to mind the sleek, square-shaped smart device that effectively puts a computer on your wrist. It's a piece of technology that has fully permeated our modern lives.

But the one Tim Cook debuted in 2014 wasn't the first Apple Watch. A little-known, largely forgotten relic of the World Wide Web era came a full two decades earlier.

Tap the link in bio to read more about Apple's 1995 watch, and what it meant for the brand.

📷: Kasia Milton

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 20, 2021. May be an image of monument, outdoors and text that says 'Live like an actual king or queenin new hotel onthe grounds of Versailles Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Staying at Le Grand Contrôle, the first hotel within the gates of the Château de Versailles, is an instant time warp back to pre-Revolutionary France. Nearly every painting, desk, mirror, and piece of tableware is a genuine Louis XVI-era antique.

The 14-room hotel occupies two standalone buildings on the south wing of Versailles—originally erected as a ducal residence in 1681—just opposite the elaborate stairways that connect the palace to the Orangerie. 

Modern comforts are hidden from view. One suite has a secret second bathroom behind an upholstered wall. There are no TVs in the rooms unless you request one, and the leather-encased iPad Pros get tucked away in an elegant leather box on antique desks. Staff can arrange concerts and dinners inside the royal apartments or an after-hours tour of the Hall of Mirrors. Period-appropriate costume photo shoots can also be arranged for a fee.

Then there’s the food. The main restaurant is led by top chef Alain Ducasse. Tap the link in our bio for more photos.

📷: Renée Kemps

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'S Elon Musk unveils the "Tesla Bot' to take over your boring work Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Elon Musk just debuted the “Tesla Bot,” a humanoid robot designed to take the drudgery out of everyday life. 

It could eliminate “dangerous, repetitive and boring tasks,” like bending over to pick something up, or go to the store for groceries, Musk said at Tesla’s AI Day. “Essentially the future of physical work will be a choice.”

A prototype should be available next year. Tap the link in our bio for more.

📷: Tesla

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'He built an $8.9 billion fortune. Then the controversies began. Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Bom Kim amassed a fortune at Coupang, the Amazon of South Korea, that reached as much as $8.9 billion, and became the poster child of a new kind of wealth generation in the country: self-made riches from technology instead of the dynastic hoards of decades-old conglomerates.

Much was made about how the new breed of titans was different, more willing to give back to society and more considerate of employees. Coupang, for example, promised staff and frontline workers about $90 million in stock awards when it listed in New York in March.

But a deadly fire at a fulfillment center in June triggered renewed criticisms about working conditions, leading to a boycott. An ill-timed public statement — the same day as the accident — on Kim’s move to step down as chief of the Korea business was widely viewed as an attempt to shirk responsibility, adding to the outrage. Read more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 19, 2021. May be an image of phone, screen and text that says 'OnlyFans to block sexually explicit videos videosstarting in October onlyrans Bloomberg'.

node.text:
OnlyFans is getting out of the pornography business, starting in October. Creators will still be allowed to post nude photos and videos, provided they’re consistent with OnlyFans’ policy.

The changes are needed because of mounting pressure from banking partners and payment providers, according to the company.

The platform has attracted more than 130 million users by giving online creators a platform to charge their fans for photos and videos. Many of its most-popular creators post nude photos and videos, and it has been praised for giving sex workers a safer place to do their jobs.

But sex work still has a stigma. And OnlyFans is trying to raise money from outside investors at a valuation of more than $1 billion.

Read more about the decision at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'WIX Amazon's $253 billion summer wipeout tests WallStreet'slove Street's Bloomberg'.

node.text:
It’s rare to see just about everyone on Wall Street agree on something, but that’s the case when it comes to Amazon. Every single analyst who rates the stock — all 55 of them — recommends clients buy it, according to Bloomberg data.

Yet that bullishness is being put to the test as last month’s unexpectedly weak sales forecast complicates the company’s growth narrative.The shares have tumbled nearly 14% from a peak in early July, erasing about $253 billion in value, as investors question its prospects on the other side of a pandemic that turbocharged demand for its services.

Amazon’s poor performance stands out among U.S. companies valued at more than $1 trillion, as well as the market as a whole. Apple, Microsoft, and Alphabet all hit records this week, as did the S&P 500 Index. Tap the link in bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Covid vaccines are less effective against delta, large study finds Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Covid-19 vaccines are less effective against the delta variant, according to results in the U.K. from one of the largest real-world studies into the shots’ efficacy.

Pfizer and BioNTech’s mRNA vaccine lost effectiveness in the first 90 days after full vaccination, though that shot and the one made by AstraZeneca still staved off a majority of Covid infections. When vaccinated people did get infected with delta, they were shown to have similar levels of virus in their bodies as those who hadn’t had shots.

This suggests that vaccinating large portions of a population might not protect those who don’t get inoculated, casting doubt on the idea of achieving herd immunity. The results are likely to fuel calls to give booster shots to the fully vaccinated even as countries around the world still lack enough supply for first immunizations. Find out more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 19, 2021. May be a meme of 1 person, beard, sitting and text that says '7 of the most influential Taliban leadersnow now running Afghanistan Bloomberg'.

node.text:
For decades, the Taliban’s leadership structure has been in the shadows. Even before the U.S. invasion in 2001, little was known about how the group operates beyond the names of a few top leaders.

Now the militants are trying to recast themselves in a more moderate light amid skepticism of their pledges to keep terrorists off Afghan soil and to grant amnesty to enemies.

So who are they? The Taliban’s senior leadership includes many Mujahideen fighters who were once trained by the U.S. during the Cold War to battle against the invading Soviet Union forces in the 1980s. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

📷: Karim Jaafar/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Nicole Kidmanis reportedly allowed toskip Hong Kong's strict quarantine Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Nicole Kidman secured an exemption from strict Hong Kong quarantine rules that have faced criticism from the financial hub’s business community, local media reported.

The actor flew into the city in a private jet that took off from Sydney on Aug. 12, according to the Standard newspaper. She arrived to shoot the “Expats” television series for Amazon and was spotted with her bodyguards in many places.

Hong Kong mandates vaccinated residents and non-residents coming from “high-risk” countries to spend as long as 21 days in hotel quarantine upon arrival, besides a host of other requirements. For those from “low-risk” places such as Australia, that is cut short to seven days plus tests followed by self-monitoring. Tap the link in our bio for more details.

📷: Leon Bennett/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 18, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Richinvestors investors Rich are buying risky credit that banks won't touch kstor Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The higher risk, higher reward world of private credit is targeting the wealthy.

Blackstone, Carlyle, Apollo and other large firms have started offering products for individuals to invest in loans to midsized companies that banks won’t touch. The lure? A potential annual return at times surpassing 8%. The risk? In private credit, lenders typically hold loans until they mature, making it more difficult for someone to pull their money out in a pinch.

The push coincides with a broader democratization in markets, with apps like Robinhood helping people find their way into everything from SPACs to Dogecoin. Find out more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 18, 2021. May be an image of child, standing, outdoors and text that says 'What sharia law could meanfor Afghan women under the Taliban'.

node.text:
One of the most urgent questions raised by the return of the Taliban to power in Afghanistan is whether the radical Islamist group will again impose draconian restrictions on women and girls.

A Taliban spokesman said on Monday that they would respect women’s rights within the framework of sharia, or Islamic law. What could that look like? See our explainer at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on August 18, 2021. May be an image of tree, mountain, sky and text that says 'The wealthiest county in America inWyoing Bloomberg'.

node.text:
When Federal Reserve officials head to their annual mountain retreat next week to talk economic inequality, they’ll be sitting in America’s wealthiest county.

Wyoming’s Teton County, home to Jackson Hole, has the nation’s highest per-capita income from assets (interests, dividends and rents), according to a study by the Economic Innovation Group. It’s a measure of wealth that excludes wages and government assistance programs and makes for about a fifth of personal income nationwide.

It’s soared in places like New York City and the San Francisco Bay Area, and stagnated across Appalachia, the Deep South. The gap between counties with the lowest and highest asset income per capita rose sixfold between 1990 and 2019. Tap the link in bio for more.
